poem:
### The Weight of Silence

Where shall we place  
the burden of innocence lost,  
when the small bodies  
lie quiet beneath a sun  
that sees too much?  
The earth mourns,  
bearing witness  
in its unyielding silence,  
as parents, hollowed by grief,  
reach for water  
in a land  
dry with sorrow.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Guardian view on the children of Gaza: when 17,000 die, it’s more than a mistake | Editorial On Sunday, an Israeli strike killed six Palestinian children – and four adults – as they queued for water in a refugee camp. The deaths of children may be the most terrible part of any war. It is not only the suffering of the innocent and powerless, and the unimaginable pain of surviving parents – as dreadful". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
